Federated Reinforcement Learning at the Edge

KonstantinosÂ Gatsis The author is with the Department of Engineering Science, University of Oxford, Parks Road, Oxford, OX1 3PJ, UK. Email: konstantinos.gatsis@eng.ox.ac.uk.
Abstract

Modern cyber-physical architectures use data collected from systems at different physical locations to learn appropriate behaviors and adapt to uncertain environments. However, an important challenge arises as communication exchanges at the edge of networked systems are costly due to limited resources. This paper considers a setup where multiple agents need to communicate efficiently in order to jointly solve a reinforcement learning problem over time-series data collected in a distributed manner. This is posed as learning an approximate value function over a communication network. An algorithm for achieving communication efficiency is proposed, supported with theoretical guarantees, practical implementations, and numerical evaluations. The approach is based on the idea of communicating only when sufficiently informative data is collected.

I Introduction

Recent years have seen a shift in cyber-physical system architectures from systems running in isolation or local networks to systems connected to the cloud for outsourcing data and computations. This has given rise to the realization that the resulting bandwidth and communication requirements can become a bottleneck, and as a result, computing at the edge of the architecture is explored. Learning and adapting to data from sensors, robots, or vehicles located at the edge enable new applications such as cloud robotics [1], connected autonomous transportation systems, and the Industrial Internet-of-Things. Toward this end, this paper introduces a new framework for performing distributed reinforcement learning from data collected locally at individual agents/robots at the edge.

The accelerating developments in machine learning and reinforcement learning have increased the interest of the control community in using data-driven techniques. Specifically in the area of control of distributed and multi-agent systems, very recent developments include algorithms for multi-agent reinforcement learning [2, 3, 4], reinforcement learning over networks/graphs [5, 6, 7, 8], as well as the search for appropriate parameterizations for these problems [9]. However when dealing with distributed learning at the edge, there is also the need for communication efficiency, especially if agents have high dimensional time-series data and operate over resource-limited communication networks.

The bulk of research in the area of distributed and communication-efficient learning, also termed federated learning, is focused on static machine learning problems, such as classification. To overcome the communication bottleneck of sending high dimensional data, the main idea is to send gradients of the objective with respect to the parameters being learned, instead of the data itself. Approaches based on gradient quantization and non-periodic updatesÂ [10, 11, 12], allocation of wireless resourcesÂ [13, 14], or approaches exploiting the informativeness of the dataÂ [15, 16] are being explored. For the problem of communication-efficient reinforcement learning, only now initial approaches emerge, including non-periodic updates for policy gradient methods [17], distributed peer-to-peer network architecturesÂ [18], specific problems such as multi-armed banditsÂ [19], or regret analysis of online distributed reinforcement learning [20].

This paper introduces a new approach for communication-efficient reinforcement learning problems. To avoid costly exchange of time-series data, agents should assess how informative are the data they collect, and communicate if the update will help the process of learning. The setup, described in SectionÂ II and shown in Fig.Â 1, involves multiple agents collecting state transitions and costs in a distributed manner for the purpose of learning approximate value functions, which is a central problem in reinforcement learning. Specifically linear value function approximation is considered. While all recent approachesÂ [17, 18, 19, 20] try to limit the amount of communication exchange during reinforcement learning, the main novelty of this paper is that the communication cost is part of the performance criterion, and the resulting advantage is that algorithms which by design efficiently tradeoff communication and learning are developed. This is obtained both theoretically (Section III) as well as in numerical examples in finite and continuous state spaces (SectionÂ V).

The approach adapts ideas from the authorâ€™s recent work on communication-efficient linear regression [15, 16] to the reinforcement learning problem. On the technical side, the approach is different here as, to ensure convergence close to an optimal solution, the agents increasingly send less informative data as the number of iterations of the learning algorithm grows. More broadly, the technical methodology relates to the problem of efficient control over networks [21, 22], event-triggered learningÂ [23, 24] and resource-aware optimizationÂ [25, 26, 27, 28].

II Problem Setup

The architecture examined in this paper, shown in Fig.Â 1, involves an access-point/server interested in solving a reinforcement learning task on data that are collected by multiple agents. Specifically, each agent is collecting independently state transitions (from a state xtsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x^{t} to a new state x+tsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x^{t}_{+}) and cost measurements (of the form ctsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡c^{t} at state xtsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x^{t}), and communicate with the server in order to jointly learn an approximate value function Vâ€‹(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥V(x) parameterized by a vector of weights wğ‘¤w. The aim will be to achieve this with communication efficiency, i.e., without agents communicating all collected data all the time. An example scenario is presented, and the formal mathematical formulation follows next.

Example 1 (Motivating scenarios).

As a first example, suppose the agents in Fig.Â 1 are robots/drones/vehicles with identical system dynamics. Then they can each collect data from their own trajectories (state transitions) as well as costs measuring how well they can achieve a common task, such as tracking a desired behavior. Transmitting all these data over the communication network would be costly. A recent case study of this form by Google [29] considers the large scale training of control and manipulation policies using multiple robots collecting image data concurrently. As a second example, suppose the agents in Fig.Â 1 are sensors/actuators in an industrial setting collecting time-series data from multiple identical physical processes, for the purpose of improving the control of the processes.

Remark 1 (Relation to other Reinforcement Learning Approaches).

In this paper we illustrate how the above value function approximation in 3 can be performed with communication efficiency. This approximation then needs to be performed at each iteration of the value iteration algorithm II-A â€“ see also AlgorithmÂ 1. The approach can also be extended to learn a Q-function approximation but this is not further discussed in this paper due to limited space. More broadly, these algorithms are variants of Projected Value IterationÂ [30, Vol. II, Ch. 6], and are behind many successful reinforcement learning approachesÂ [32, 33]. These algorithms are attractive because under technical conditions they converge to a unique point.

II-B Communication-efficient reinforcement learning problem

Given the above modeling for a reinforcement learning task that needs to be solved, the communication problem is as follows. At each iteration kğ‘˜k, the server broadcasts the current weights wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k} to all agents. Then each agent iğ‘–i collects Tğ‘‡T local data samples identically distributed (across samples and across agents), computes a local stochastic gradient âˆ‡^iâ€‹Jâ€‹(wk)subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k}) from the available local data using formula 5, and decides whether to transmit this gradient update over the communication network to the receiving server. The server updates the current vector of weights wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k} depending on the information received from different agents. For simplicity of exposition the case of two agents is considered and theoretically analyzed, and experiments with more agents are conducted numerically in SectionÂ V. This leads to the update rule at the server

wk+1={wkâˆ’Îµâ€‹âˆ‡^1â€‹Jâ€‹(wk)ifÂ 1Â transmitswkâˆ’Îµâ€‹âˆ‡^2â€‹Jâ€‹(wk)ifÂ 2Â transmitswkâˆ’Îµ2â€‹(âˆ‡^1â€‹Jâ€‹(wk)+âˆ‡^2â€‹Jâ€‹(wk))if both transmitwkif no transmitssubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1casessubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğœ€subscript^âˆ‡1ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ifÂ 1Â transmitssubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğœ€subscript^âˆ‡2ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ifÂ 2Â transmitssubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğœ€2subscript^âˆ‡1ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscript^âˆ‡2ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜if both transmitsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜if no transmitsw_{k+1}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}w_{k}-\varepsilon\hat{\nabla}_{1}J(w_{k})&\text{if $1$ transmits}\\ w_{k}-\varepsilon\hat{\nabla}_{2}J(w_{k})&\text{if $2$ transmits}\\ w_{k}-\frac{\varepsilon}{2}(\hat{\nabla}_{1}J(w_{k})+\hat{\nabla}_{2}J(w_{k}))&\text{if both transmit}\\ w_{k}&\text{if no transmits}\end{array}\right. (6)

We further denote with Î±kiâˆˆ{1,0}superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘–10\alpha_{k}^{i}\in\{1,0\} the decision for each agent i=1,2ğ‘–12i=1,2 to transmit or not.

At the next iteration k+1ğ‘˜1k+1 a new set of data is collected at each agent, a new stochastic gradient direction âˆ‡^iâ€‹Jâ€‹(wk+1)subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k+1}) with respect to the new vector wk+1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1w_{k+1} is computed at each agent, and the process repeats until a final iteration Nğ‘N. The algorithm is also described in AlgorithmÂ 1.

The aim will be to avoid sending updates all the time in order to limit the communication burden. Hence we consider the average communication cost during all iterations and across all agents as

On the other hand, we want to understand the progress of learning, hence we also measure how well the final set of weights wNsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘w_{N} solves 3, in other words we measure the cost function Jâ€‹(wN)ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘J(w_{N}).

We note that since the data points at each iteration and at each agent are random, so are the constructed stochastic gradient directions, and so are the vectors wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k}, and so are the decisions Î±kisuperscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘–\alpha_{k}^{i} of the agents to transmit. We propose then to measure the efficiency of the implementation on average over the data points collected. As a result, we establish the performance metric

ğ”¼dataâ€‹[Î»â€‹âˆ‘k=0Nâˆ’1Î±k1+Î±k22â€‹N+Jâ€‹(wN)]subscriptğ”¼datadelimited-[]ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜1superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜22ğ‘ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘\mathbb{E}_{\text{data}}\left[\lambda\sum_{k=0}^{N-1}\,\frac{\alpha_{k}^{1}+\alpha_{k}^{2}}{2N}+J(w_{N})\right] (8)

Here Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0 is a tuning parameter that is used to either penalize communication or learning performance. It is worth emphasizing then that there are two expectations in this paper. One is the integral defined in the objective Jâ€‹(w)ğ½ğ‘¤J(w) in 3, and another is the expected performance of the implementation in 8 computed as an integral over tuples xt,ct,x+t+1superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1x^{t},c^{t},x_{+}^{t+1} â€“ in total 2â€‹Nâ€‹T2ğ‘ğ‘‡2NT tuples over agents, iterations, and samples â€“ and denoted as ğ”¼datasubscriptğ”¼data\mathbb{E}_{\text{data}} to clarify the difference.

III Theoretical scheme for communication-efficient reinforcement learning

The approach is based on the notion of performance gain which can be thought as a measure of how informative are the data collected at each agent at each time step with respect to the reinforcement learning problem. The gain at agent i=1,2ğ‘–12i=1,2 can be calculated by measuring how much will the objective change if the agent sends the update. Whether this gain is negative or positive depends on the random direction of the update. The proposed approach then is to send a gradient update if the gain is large enough. Mathematically we write

Î±ki={1ifÂ â€‹Jâ€‹(wkâˆ’Îµâ€‹âˆ‡^iâ€‹Jâ€‹(wk))âˆ’Jâ€‹(wk)â‰¤âˆ’Î»ÏNâˆ’1âˆ’k0otherwisesuperscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘–cases1ifÂ ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğœ€subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğœ†superscriptğœŒğ‘1ğ‘˜0otherwise\alpha_{k}^{i}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}1&\text{if }J(w_{k}-\varepsilon\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k}))-J(w_{k})\leq-\frac{\lambda}{\rho^{N-1-k}}\\ 0&\text{otherwise}\end{array}\right. (9)

where the scalar parameter Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0 is the one defined in the performance criterion, and Ïâˆˆ(0,1)ğœŒ01\rho\in(0,1) is a parameter â€“ whose impact is further discussed in the theoretical results below. Intuitively this approach saves up communication resources, because the updates will be infrequent. Moreover, the term at the right hand side, which measures how informative are the data at the current iteration, is decreasing (in absolute value) as the number of iterations grow. Hence, at the beginning only very informative updates are transmitted, while as learning progresses, less informative updates are transmitted as well.

Assumption 1.

The nÃ—nğ‘›ğ‘›n\times n symmetric matrix ğ”¼dâ€‹Ï•â€‹(x)â€‹Ï•â€‹(x)Tsubscriptğ”¼ğ‘‘italic-Ï•ğ‘¥italic-Ï•superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡\mathbb{E}_{d}\phi(x)\phi(x)^{T} is positive definite.

This assumption guarantees the solution to the main problem 3 is unique.

Assumption 2.

The step size Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0 in 6 satisfies

|1âˆ’2â€‹Îµâ€‹Î»iâ€‹(ğ”¼dâ€‹Ï•â€‹(x)â€‹Ï•â€‹(x)T)|<112ğœ€subscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğ”¼ğ‘‘italic-Ï•ğ‘¥italic-Ï•superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡1\left|1-2\varepsilon\lambda_{i}(\mathbb{E}_{d}\phi(x)\phi(x)^{T})\right|<1 (10)

for all eigenvalues of the matrix at the right hand side.

This assumption guarantees the step size is small enough so that convergence, even without communication constraints, is satisfied. A sufficient condition is Îµ<2/Î»maxğœ€2subscriptğœ†\varepsilon<2/\lambda_{\max} where Î»maxsubscriptğœ†\lambda_{\max} is the largest eigenvalue of the above matrix. Assumption 1 guarantees that 10 can be met.

Assumption 3.

The parameter ÏğœŒ\rho in 9 satisfies

Ïâ‰¥maxi(1âˆ’2ÎµÎ»i(ğ”¼dÏ•(x)Ï•(x)T))2\rho\geq\max_{i}(1-2\varepsilon\lambda_{i}(\mathbb{E}_{d}\phi(x)\phi(x)^{T}))^{2} (11)

for all eigenvalues of the matrix at the right hand side.

This assumption states that measuring the informativeness of the data should decrease at a sufficiently slow rate. Assumptions 2 and 3 together guarantee that Ï<1ğœŒ1\rho<1 is a possible choice.

The main theoretical result of this paper is established next.

Theorem 1 (Communication-Efficient Value Function Approximation).

Consider the optimization problem defined in 3. Consider the update rule in 6. Suppose âˆ‡^iâ€‹Jâ€‹(wk),i=1,2,formulae-sequencesubscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘–12\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k}),i=1,2, are independent random variables with mean equal to âˆ‡Jâ€‹(wk)âˆ‡ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜\nabla J(w_{k}) and covariance GğºG at each iteration kğ‘˜k. Consider the communication strategy in 9 with a fixed number of iterations Nğ‘N. Let Assumptions 1-3 hold. Then we have that

ğ”¼dataâ€‹[Î»â€‹âˆ‘k=0Nâˆ’1Î±k1+Î±k22â€‹N+Jâ€‹(wN)]â‰¤Î»+Jâ€‹(wâˆ—)subscriptğ”¼datadelimited-[]ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜1superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜22ğ‘ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘ğœ†ğ½superscriptğ‘¤\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\text{data}}\left[\lambda\sum_{k=0}^{N-1}\frac{\alpha_{k}^{1}+\alpha_{k}^{2}}{2N}+J(w_{N})\right]\leq\lambda+J(w^{*})
+ÏNâ€‹[Jâ€‹(w0)âˆ’Jâ€‹(wâˆ—)]+1âˆ’ÏN1âˆ’Ïâ€‹Îµ2â€‹Trâ€‹(ğ”¼dâ€‹Ï•â€‹(x)â€‹Ï•â€‹(x)Tâ€‹G)superscriptğœŒğ‘delimited-[]ğ½subscriptğ‘¤0ğ½superscriptğ‘¤1superscriptğœŒğ‘1ğœŒsuperscriptğœ€2Trsubscriptğ”¼ğ‘‘italic-Ï•ğ‘¥italic-Ï•superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğº\displaystyle+\rho^{N}[J(w_{0})-J(w^{*})]+\frac{1-\rho^{N}}{1-\rho}\varepsilon^{2}\text{Tr}(\mathbb{E}_{d}\phi(x)\phi(x)^{T}G) (12)

where wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*} is the optimal solution of 3 and the expectation is with respect to the data collected until iteration Nğ‘N.

We have the following observations. The terms on the right hand side of 1 measure the suboptimality of learning, including the terms that have to do with the poor initialization Jâ€‹(w0)âˆ’Jâ€‹(wâˆ—)ğ½subscriptğ‘¤0ğ½superscriptğ‘¤J(w_{0})-J(w^{*}) and the noise of the gradients captured by the matrix GğºG. As the number of iterations Nğ‘N grows, the impact of the former is diminished, and only the latter remains. This expression also suggests that ideally one would pick the parameter ÏğœŒ\rho to be the minimum allowed by the above Assumption 3.

The theorem characterizes the tradeoff between communication and learning. By increasing the parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda, there is a higher penalty for communicating, and as a result, the agents communicate less often â€” see following remark. As a consequence, learning performance will be impacted. But the above theorem guarantees by design that there will be a graceful compromise between communication performance and learning â€“ the left hand side 1 cannot be arbitrarily poor.

It is worth noting that, essentially, from the right hand side of 1, the theorem states that the aggregate performance will be better than just having one agent only and transmitting all the time. It is possible to extend the analysis to get bounds sharper than 1, which will be the topic of future work.

Remark 2.

In TheoremÂ 1 we assumed for simplicity that the stochastic gradients have bounded covariances that are constant over time. In reality for the problem above the covariance of the stochastic gradient in 5 will depend on the current iterate wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k}, but our choice can be justified. For example we can add a projection to a bounded set â€–wkâ€–<Mnormsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘€\|w_{k}\|<M in the algorithm, so we only search over this restricted set of weights, resulting in bounded gradient noise covariances.

Remark 3 (Analysis over mutiple iterations).

The above theoretical analysis is performed for one iteration of Alg.Â 1 (lines 5-9). As a result, at each iteration communication-efficiency is guaranteed. After many iterations, the algorithm will converge to a neighborhood of the desired set of weights wğ‘¤w, i.e., the value function approximation. This analysis will be explored in future work.

IV Practical scheme for communication-efficient reinforcement learning

Despite the above guarantee, implementing the theoretical communication scheme in 9 would be practically impossible because it requires information that is not known. Specifically it would require for every agent to know the Markov Decision Process and the data distribution in order to compute the actual performance gain. Since these are unknown, one approach is to estimate the performance gain from the data. In particular, since the objective function is quadratic, we can write the performance gain as

Jâ€‹(wkâˆ’Îµâ€‹âˆ‡^iâ€‹Jâ€‹(wk))âˆ’Jâ€‹(wk)=âˆ’Îµâ€‹âˆ‡^iâ€‹Jâ€‹(wk)Tâ€‹âˆ‡Jâ€‹(wk)ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğœ€subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğœ€subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ½superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘‡âˆ‡ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜\displaystyle J\left(w_{k}-\varepsilon\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})\right)-J(w_{k})=-\varepsilon\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})^{T}\nabla J(w_{k})
+12â€‹Îµ2â€‹âˆ‡^iâ€‹Jâ€‹(wk)Tâ€‹âˆ‡2Jâ€‹(wk)â€‹âˆ‡^iâ€‹Jâ€‹(wk)12superscriptğœ€2subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ½superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘‡superscriptâˆ‡2ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜\displaystyle+\frac{1}{2}\varepsilon^{2}\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})^{T}\nabla^{2}J(w_{k})\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k}) (13)

This is a quadratic function of the stochastic gradient âˆ‡^iâ€‹Jâ€‹(wk)subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k}). Then we can approximate the gradient and the Hessian at each agent as

âˆ‡Jâ€‹(wk)â‰ˆâˆ‡^iâ€‹Jâ€‹(wk)âˆ‡ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜\displaystyle\nabla J(w_{k})\approx\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})
âˆ‡2Jâ€‹(wk)â‰ˆ1Tâ€‹âˆ‘t=0TÏ•â€‹(xt)â€‹Ï•â€‹(xt)Tsuperscriptâˆ‡2ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡italic-Ï•superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-Ï•superscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘‡\displaystyle\nabla^{2}J(w_{k})\approx\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\phi(x^{t})\phi(x^{t})^{T} (14)

Hence, using the expression for the information gain in IV, we can approximate the gain at agent i=1,2ğ‘–12i=1,2 as222Overall at each agent these computations require Oâ€‹(Tâ€‹n)ğ‘‚ğ‘‡ğ‘›O(Tn) operations hence are scalable.

Jâ€‹(wkâˆ’Îµâ€‹âˆ‡^iâ€‹Jâ€‹(wk))âˆ’Jâ€‹(wk)â‰ˆğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğœ€subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜absent\displaystyle J\left(w_{k}-\varepsilon\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})\right)-J(w_{k})\approx
âˆ’âˆ‡^iâ€‹Jâ€‹(wk)Tâ€‹[Iâˆ’Îµâ€‹12â€‹1Tâ€‹âˆ‘t=0TÏ•â€‹(xt)â€‹Ï•â€‹(xt)T]â€‹âˆ‡^iâ€‹Jâ€‹(wk)Tsubscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ½superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘‡delimited-[]ğ¼ğœ€121ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡italic-Ï•superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-Ï•superscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘‡subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ½superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘‡\displaystyle-\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})^{T}\left[I-\varepsilon\frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\phi(x^{t})\phi(x^{t})^{T}\right]\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})^{T} (15)

It is important to emphasize that this is no longer a simple quadratic function of the stochastic gradient but a more complicated function - we note that the data appear both in the stochastic gradients as well as in the matrix in the middle. This approximate value of the gain may take again positive or negative values but it induces an approximation error/bias.

As a result, we can implement the communication decision in 9 with the approximation in IV. In this case we no longer have the performance guarantee in TheoremÂ 1. In numerical evaluations however we see that despite the bias this mechanism performs very well.

Remark 4.

Another intuitive approach to evaluate the informativeness of the data is to assume that the performance gain IV is large when the stochastic gradient has a large norm â€–âˆ‡^iâ€‹Jâ€‹(wk)â€–normsubscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜\|\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})\| at an agent. However, recent workÂ [15, 16] has demonstrated that this approach is not necessarily communication-efficient. A different perspective is followed by [17]. When agents do not update their gradients at the server, the server keeps a memory of past received gradients and uses them for gradient descent in 6. The advantage of the present approach is that it introduces an explicit communication-learning tradeoff that can be controlled by the parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda. Technically, the approach [17] is developed for policy gradient methods, while here the approach is developed for value-function-based approaches.

V Numerical results

We consider first a grid exploration example (Fig.Â 2) which is a finite state Markov Decision Process with state space Xğ‘‹X. An agent can move in four directions subject to the boundary constraints, while at the top part of the grid there is a 50% uncertainty in transitions to the right because of disturbances. The objective function is the total undiscounted (Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1) time it takes to reach a desired goal location G. We collect measurements from multiple agents following the policy that randomizes over all actions at each state.

We perform one iteration of AlgorithmÂ 1 following II-A where the initial value function is chosen randomly. In order to learn the exact value function we take the basis functions/features to be the indicators Ï•â€‹(1)=[1,0,â€¦,0]T,Ï•â€‹(2)=[0,1,0,â€¦,0]Tformulae-sequenceitalic-Ï•1superscript10â€¦0ğ‘‡italic-Ï•2superscript010â€¦0ğ‘‡\phi(1)=[1,0,\ldots,0]^{T},\phi(2)=[0,1,0,\ldots,0]^{T}, etc in 2. We suppose each agent has few data tuples T=10ğ‘‡10T=10 in every iteration, as described in SectionÂ II, chosen from a uniform distribution dğ‘‘d on this finite state space, and we take the stepsize to be Îµ=1ğœ€1\varepsilon=1. We implement the theoretical approach 9 and the practical approach using IV. We pick the parameter ÏğœŒ\rho to be close to its smallest value allowed by Assumption 3. For varying values of the parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda we empirically compute the average communication rate 7, and the average final learning performance Jâ€‹(wN)ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘J(w_{N}) as defined in 3. The achieved tradeoff between the two is shown in Fig.Â 2. As a comparison, we also include the results when agents randomly decide whether the transmit their gradients or not, leading to an inefficient outcome.

For the theoretical algorithm 9, we observe that a very high communication efficiency can be achieved, i.e., by transmitting only a fraction of the time it is possible to find very good solutions to the value function approximation problem, hence achieving a good communication-learning tradeoff. For the practical approach using IV of course the learning loss is higher due to the bias introduced, but we also clearly observe a very good tradeoff between all agents communicating all the time versus scarce communications only when necessary.

Then for a more complicated scenario we consider a continuous (uncountable) state space problem X=â„2ğ‘‹superscriptâ„2X={\mathbb{R}}^{2}. State transitions are given by a stochastic linear dynamical system x+=Aâ€‹x+wsubscriptğ‘¥ğ´ğ‘¥ğ‘¤x_{+}=Ax+w, with A=[0.8âˆ’0.20.11]ğ´delimited-[]0.80.20.11A=\left[\begin{array}[]{cc}0.8&-0.2\\ 0.1&1\end{array}\right], where wğ‘¤w is a zero-mean Gaussian noise variable with covariance 0.10.10.1. We also consider a quadratic cost câ€‹(x)=â€–xâ€–2ğ‘ğ‘¥superscriptnormğ‘¥2c(x)=\|x\|^{2} and a discount factor Î³=0.9ğ›¾0.9\gamma=0.9. We want to perform one value iteration following II-A where the initial value function is chosen randomly. We would like to approximate the updated value function per 2 as a linear combination of polynomial functions of the states with maximum degree 2 â€“ that is Ï•â€‹(x)=[x12,x22,x1â€‹x2,x1,x2,1]Tâˆˆâ„6italic-Ï•ğ‘¥superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥12superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥22subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥21ğ‘‡superscriptâ„6\phi(x)=[x_{1}^{2},x_{2}^{2},x_{1}x_{2},x_{1},x_{2},1]^{T}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{6} â€“ and we are searching for a vector of weights wâˆˆâ„6ğ‘¤superscriptâ„6w\in{\mathbb{R}}^{6}. We suppose each agent has at every iteration T=103ğ‘‡superscript103T=10^{3} data tuples, as described in SectionÂ II, chosen from a uniform distribution dğ‘‘d on the space [0,1]2superscript012[0,1]^{2}. We take the stepsize to be Îµ=1ğœ€1\varepsilon=1 and the parameter Ï=0.999ğœŒ0.999\rho=0.999. As expected when learning value functions on continuous state space, in this case we need many more iterations and a larger amount of data, in the order of 108superscript10810^{8} data tuples.

We implement the practical communication algorithm with IV. Fig.Â 3 shows the evolution of weights for a large penalty Î»ğœ†\lambda on communication rate. The figure shows that at the beginning no communication takes place because not very high informative gradients are found, while more communication takes place as learning progresses. Fig.Â 3 shows the same setup with a smaller penalty Î»ğœ†\lambda on communication, and we observe higher communication rate and faster learning of the weights. These observations verify the findings of TheoremÂ 1. Finally Fig.Â 3 shows the same setup but with a larger number of agents, 10 instead of 2. We observe that learning happens faster, with almost the same amount of average communication rate. This observation is not yet studied theoretically here and will be explored in future work.

VI Concluding remarks

This paper examines the problem of solving reinforcement learning tasks over a network. To exploit the informativeness of the data, the notion of performance gain is explored and is shown numerically how this can be approximated from the data without further model knowledge. The approach is supported theoretically and numerically. Ongoing work explores the use of the approach in more complex networks and reinforcement learning algorithms.

-B Proof of 27

Within this proof we drop the iteration index kğ‘˜k. Let us denote by Fâ€‹(g)ğ¹ğ‘”F(g) the distribution of the stochastic gradient g:=âˆ‡^â€‹Jâ€‹(wk)assignğ‘”^âˆ‡ğ½subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜g:=\hat{\nabla}J(w_{k}) at any agent. Then we can rewrite 27 as

âˆ«Î±â€‹(g)â€‹Jâ€‹(wâˆ’Îµâ€‹g)â€‹ğ‘‘Fâ€‹(g)â‰¤âˆ«Î±â€‹(g)â€‹ğ‘‘Fâ€‹(g)â€‹âˆ«Jâ€‹(wâˆ’Îµâ€‹g)â€‹ğ‘‘Fâ€‹(g)ğ›¼ğ‘”ğ½ğ‘¤ğœ€ğ‘”differential-dğ¹ğ‘”ğ›¼ğ‘”differential-dğ¹ğ‘”ğ½ğ‘¤ğœ€ğ‘”differential-dğ¹ğ‘”\int\alpha(g)J(w-\varepsilon g)dF(g)\leq\int\alpha(g)dF(g)\int J(w-\varepsilon g)dF(g) (38)

âˆ«SJâ€‹(wâˆ’Îµâ€‹g)â€‹ğ‘‘Fâ€‹(g)â‰¤subscriptğ‘†ğ½ğ‘¤ğœ€ğ‘”differential-dğ¹ğ‘”absent\displaystyle\int_{S}J(w-\varepsilon g)dF(g)\leq

âˆ«Scğ‘‘Fâ€‹(g)â€‹âˆ«SJâ€‹(wâˆ’Îµâ€‹g)â€‹ğ‘‘Fâ€‹(g)â‰¤âˆ«Sğ‘‘Fâ€‹(g)â€‹âˆ«ScJâ€‹(wâˆ’Îµâ€‹g)â€‹ğ‘‘Fâ€‹(g)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†ğ‘differential-dğ¹ğ‘”subscriptğ‘†ğ½ğ‘¤ğœ€ğ‘”differential-dğ¹ğ‘”subscriptğ‘†differential-dğ¹ğ‘”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†ğ‘ğ½ğ‘¤ğœ€ğ‘”differential-dğ¹ğ‘”\displaystyle\int_{S^{c}}dF(g)\int_{S}J(w-\varepsilon g)dF(g)\leq\int_{S}dF(g)\int_{S^{c}}J(w-\varepsilon g)dF(g) (40)

âˆ«Sğ‘‘Fâ€‹(g)â€‹âˆ«ScJâ€‹(wâˆ’Îµâ€‹g)â€‹ğ‘‘Fâ€‹(g)â‰¥âˆ«Sğ‘‘Fâ€‹(g)â€‹âˆ«Scğ‘‘Fâ€‹(g)â€‹[Jâ€‹(w)âˆ’Î»]subscriptğ‘†differential-dğ¹ğ‘”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†ğ‘ğ½ğ‘¤ğœ€ğ‘”differential-dğ¹ğ‘”subscriptğ‘†differential-dğ¹ğ‘”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†ğ‘differential-dğ¹ğ‘”delimited-[]ğ½ğ‘¤ğœ†\displaystyle\int_{S}dF(g)\int_{S^{c}}J(w-\varepsilon g)dF(g)\geq\int_{S}dF(g)\int_{S^{c}}dF(g)\;[J(w)-\lambda] (42)
